data.title: Kiichi Miyazawa
data.meta_description: In a land where politicians have reached their career peak habitually at an age when Western counterparts have long since penned their memoirs, Kiichi Miyazawa’s tenure as Japanese Prime Minister in
data.text:
In a land where politicians have reached their career peak habitually at an age when Western counterparts have long since penned their memoirs, Kiichi Miyazawa’s tenure as Japanese Prime Minister in his early seventies was marked less by advancing years than ill-luck in leading the Liberal Democratic Party in 1993 to its first electoral defeat in nearly 40 years.

But where Miyazawa did stand out was that in 1998 he agreed to return as Finance Minister. Then, old even by Japanese standards, his readiness to meet the stern demands of international summitry and policy processes implied either that there lay within him a palpable devotion to duty, or that he believed he could diffuse Japan’s economic crisis personally.

That he failed repeatedly to enact economic
